title: Maps
text:
This page showcases interactive maps and dashboards that communicate geospatial data effectively. Below is an example of a dashboard created on ArcGIS Online to visualize positive COVID-19 cases per MODZCTA (Modified Zip Code Tabulation Areas) in New York City.




 






Hotspots: Areas with the highest concentration of positive cases.
Trends Over Time: Use the time slider to see how cases evolved during the pandemic.
Demographics: Explore how different neighborhoods were affected.

title: William Cornejo Portfolio
text:
In past public health crises, visuals have proven to be one of the most effective ways to communicate data efficiently. Florence Nightingale’s work during the Crimean War used a “Coxcomb” diagram to visually represent the causes of soldier mortality, highlighting that the majority of deaths were due to preventable infections rather than battlefield injuries. Her work led to significant improvements in sanitation and medical care, reducing death rates (Source: Nightingale, 1858).
Today, in an era of rapid urbanization and global connectivity, web maps should be the primary medium for sharing information about health hazards in cities. By leveraging GIS, we can provide real-time, actionable insights to policymakers, healthcare providers, and the public.
This project serves as a call to action for NYC officials, emphasizing the critical role that map data can play in addressing public health emergencies like the COVID-19 pandemic.
